Phishing-Angriffe, gefÃ¤lschte Wallets oder kompromittierte Computer sind die grÃ¶ÃŸten Risiken. Wer seinen Private Key oder Seed-WÃ¶rter online speichert, begibt sich in Lebensgefahr â€“ zumindest finanziell. Auch der Verlust einer Wallet ohne Backup fÃ¼hrt unweigerlich zum Totalverlust. 

Die beste Strategie ist Selbstverwahrung: Nutze Hardware Wallets, sichere deine Seed-Phrase offline und Ã¼berprÃ¼fe regelmÃ¤ÃŸig die IntegritÃ¤t deiner GerÃ¤te. Zudem ist es ratsam, fÃ¼r grÃ¶ÃŸere BetrÃ¤ge Cold-Storage-LÃ¶sungen zu verwenden, also Systeme, die komplett vom Internet getrennt sind. 

Auch rechtliche und steuerliche Aspekte sollten Nutzer kennen. In vielen LÃ¤ndern gelten Gewinne aus dem Handel mit Bitcoin als steuerpflichtig. Eine transparente Dokumentation aller Transaktionen ist daher nicht nur klug, sondern notwendig. 

Das VerstÃ¤ndnis darÃ¼ber, wie eine Bitcoin-Adresse funktioniert, ist die Grundlage fÃ¼r jede Form von sicherer und verantwortungsvoller Nutzung dieser Technologie. 

 
Zusammenfassung 

Eine Bitcoin-Adresse ist weit mehr als nur eine digitale Kontonummer. Sie ist das Ergebnis einer ausgeklÃ¼gelten Kryptografie, die Besitz und Kontrolle dezentral organisiert. Jede Adresse entsteht aus einem einzigartigen SchlÃ¼sselpaar, das mathematisch miteinander verknÃ¼pft ist. WÃ¤hrend der Public Key Ã¶ffentlich genutzt wird, bleibt der Private Key streng geheim â€“ er ist der einzige Zugang zu den eigenen Coins. 

Die verschiedenen Adressformate â€“ Legacy, SegWit und Bech32 â€“ zeigen die technische Weiterentwicklung des Bitcoin-Protokolls. Durch sie wurde das Netzwerk effizienter, gÃ¼nstiger und benutzerfreundlicher. 

Bitcoin-Adressen sind pseudonym, transparent und sicher â€“ solange der Nutzer verantwortungsvoll handelt. Wer versteht, wie sie funktionieren, erkennt den wahren Wert von Bitcoin: vÃ¶llige finanzielle Eigenverantwortung und UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit. 

 
HÃ¤ufige Fragen (FAQ) 

Was ist der Unterschied zwischen einer Bitcoin-Adresse und einer Wallet?
Eine Wallet ist eine Software oder Hardware, die Private Keys verwaltet und Transaktionen signiert. Eine Bitcoin-Adresse ist nur eine Empfangsadresse innerhalb dieser Wallet. Eine Wallet kann Hunderte von Adressen enthalten. 

Kann ich mehrere Bitcoin-Adressen haben?
Ja. Du kannst unbegrenzt viele Adressen erzeugen â€“ kostenlos und anonym. Das regelmÃ¤ÃŸige Erstellen neuer Adressen erhÃ¶ht deine PrivatsphÃ¤re. 

Was passiert, wenn ich meine Bitcoin-Adresse falsch eingebe?
Dank der eingebauten PrÃ¼fsumme wird eine falsch eingegebene Adresse meist sofort als ungÃ¼ltig erkannt. Wird eine gÃ¼ltige, aber falsche Adresse verwendet, ist das Geld allerdings verloren. 

Wie kann ich eine Bitcoin-Adresse erstellen?
Am einfachsten Ã¼ber eine Wallet-App. Diese generiert automatisch Private und Public Keys sowie die dazugehÃ¶rige Adresse â€“ ohne dass du dich registrieren musst. 

Sind Bitcoin-Adressen wirklich anonym?
Nein, sie sind pseudonym. Alle Transaktionen sind Ã¶ffentlich einsehbar, aber nicht direkt mit deiner IdentitÃ¤t verknÃ¼pft, solange du keine persÃ¶nlichen Daten preisgibst. 

Wie sicher ist eine Bitcoin-Adresse?
Extrem sicher â€“ solange dein Private Key geheim bleibt. Die kryptografische Struktur ist so stark, dass ein Angriff mathematisch praktisch unmÃ¶glich ist. 

Kann ich meine alte Bitcoin-Adresse weiterverwenden?
Ja, aber es ist ratsam, fÃ¼r neue Transaktionen neue Adressen zu verwenden. Das erhÃ¶ht deine PrivatsphÃ¤re und erschwert die Nachverfolgung deiner Zahlungen.

item.title: Stephan Livera Podcast â€“ Hash-based signatures for Bitcoin's post-quantum future? with Jonas Nick | SLP713
item.description:
In this conversation, Stephan Livera and Jonas Nick discuss the implications of quantum computing on Bitcoin's security, focusing on the risks posed to cryptographic signatures. They explore the current vulnerabilities in Bitcoin, the potential for quantum attacks, and the need for post-quantum cryptographic solutions. The discussion covers various signature schemes, including hash-based signatures, their trade-offs, and the challenges of transitioning to a quantum-resistant Bitcoin. They also touch on the implications for hardware wallets, multi-signature schemes, and the potential need for block size increases to accommodate new signature sizes.

Takeaways:

ğŸ”¸Quantum computers pose a real risk to Bitcoin's cryptography.

ğŸ”¸Current Bitcoin signatures are vulnerable to long-range attacks.

ğŸ”¸Hash-based signatures are significantly larger than current signatures.

ğŸ”¸Transitioning to quantum resistance will require careful planning.

ğŸ”¸The Bitcoin community must reach a consensus on new schemes.

ğŸ”¸Verification costs will increase with new signature schemes.

ğŸ”¸Hardware wallets will need to adapt to new signature requirements.

ğŸ”¸Block size discussions may need to be revisited in light of quantum risks.

ğŸ”¸The timeline for quantum computing advancements is uncertain.

ğŸ”¸A gradual transition to quantum resistance may be necessary.Â 

Timestamps:

(00:00) - Intro

(01:49) - How real is quantum risk to Bitcoin?

(04:39) - When could quantum pose a threat to Bitcoinâ€™s cryptography?Â 

(09:56) - Long range vs Short range attacks

(12:37) - How many coins are vulnerable to Long range attacks?

(14:12) - Different types of cryptography and exploring Hash-based signature schemes

(17:00) - Categories of Hash-based signature scheme and their pros & cons

(23:42) - How do Hash-based signatures work?Â 

(32:14) - Would Lightning, Multi-sig, Taproot, Silent Payments, Atomic swaps work in a post-quantum world?Â 

(38:50) - What are Adaptor signatures & how do they affect atomic swapping?Â 

(41:27) - Will we need new Bitcoin hardware wallets?; Signature production & verificationÂ 

(44:41) - Signature size and Bitcoin block capacity implications

(46:52) - Should we revisit the block size conversation?Â 

(54:57) - Overview of SPHINCS+ & SHRINCS

(59:49) - Transitioning to post-quantum signature schemes; Overview of BIP 360

(1:09:06) - Closing thoughts

item.title: Blockspace: A Bitcoin Podcast â€“ ENERGY: Understanding ERCOTâ€™s Massive Overhaul w/ Tom Kleckner
item.description:
Subscribe to the Blockspace newsletter!


Welcome back to The Blockspace Podcast! Today, Tom Kleckner, a veteran energy correspondent at RTO Insider, joins us to talk about how ERCOT is overhauling the Texas grid to handle the unprecedented AI boom. We dive into the massive 233GW interconnection queue, the impact of Senate Bill 6 on transmission costs, and new reliability measures like DRRS. Tom breaks down the "batch process" for large loads and whether Bitcoin miners or AI data centers are better at balancing the grid. We also touch on the future of Texas energy, from gas plants to small modular nuclear reactors.


Subscribe to the newsletter! https://newsletter.blockspacemedia.com


Notes:

* 70% demand jump to 145GW by 2031.

* Interconnection queue reached 233GW.

* SB6 shifts transmission costs to large loads.

* Large loads defined as 75MW or greater.

* Texas Energy Fund has $10 billion available.

* 73% of queue requests from data centers.


Timestamps:

00:00 Start

01:51 Interconnection queue changes

06:46 Kill switch

item.title: Bitcoin Policy Institute â€“ Congressman Warren Davidson Unveils the â€œBitcoin for America Actâ€ | Spotlight Series #1
item.description:
In this exclusive interview, Congressman Warren Davidson announces the introduction of the Bitcoin for America Act, legislation that could redefine how the United States adopts Bitcoin and how Americans fulfill their tax obligations.Hosted by Conner Brown, Head of Strategy at the Bitcoin Policy Institute (BPI), this premiere episode of the BPI Spotlight Series explores:â€¢ Codifying the Strategic Bitcoin Reserveâ€¢ Allowing Americans to pay federal taxes in Bitcoinâ€¢ Eliminating capital gains taxes when Bitcoin is used for tax paymentsâ€¢ Strengthening national security and economic resilience through sound moneyâ€¢ Preserving financial privacy in a digital eraâ€¢ Encouraging grassroots adoption and opt-in contributions to a national Bitcoin reserveâ€¢ Reestablishing the United States as the global leader in Bitcoin innovationWhy it matters:The United States faces unprecedented debt pressures and growing competition over the future of money. Davidson argues that Bitcoin provides a durable path toward financial stability, technological leadership, and renewed economic freedom for the American people.Key topics covered:â€¢ Bitcoin tax reform and de minimis payment exemptionsâ€¢ National competitiveness in the digital asset economyâ€¢ Inflation, fiscal policy, and sovereign savings strategyâ€¢ CBDC risks and the importance of privacy-preserving moneyâ€¢ Gen Z financial opportunity and long-term savingsFor viewers interested in Bitcoin policy, economic strategy, and Americaâ€™s financial future, this discussion offers essential insight into how forward-looking legislation could shape the decades ahead.Contact your elected representatives and encourage support for the Bitcoin for America Act.Subscribe for more policy-focused interviews and expert research from the Bitcoin Policy Institute.

]]>

item.title: Rob Wallace | Bitcoin News â€“ Satoshiâ€™s Coins at Risk: Quantum Computers Could Steal 30% of BTC | Charles Edwards
item.description:
Is Bitcoin facing an existential crisis? Rob Wallace sits down with Charles Edwards, founder of Capriole Investments, to discuss the 2026 outlook for Bitcoin and the broader macro markets.

Following a major technical breakout above $93,500, Charles explains how an $11 trillion surge in global money supply is fueling the next leg up for risk assets.

However, the conversation takes a serious turn as they discuss "Q-Day," the day quantum computers could potentially break Bitcoin's encryption. With a 20-30% probability of this occurring by 2028, Charles lays out the urgent roadmap for BIP 360 and the philosophical battle over whether to "burn" or "hack" Satoshiâ€™s 1.1 million coins.

]]>

item.title: Bitcoin, Fiat & Rock'n'Roll â€“ Running Stablecoins at Scale - with Max von Wallenberg from MoonPay
item.description:
Stablecoins are no longer a thought experimentâ€”theyâ€™re becoming production infrastructure. In this episode of Bitcoin, Fiat & Rock and Roll, we sit down with Max von Wallenberg, a builder whoâ€™s seen markets from every angle: trading floors at Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs, leadership at BÃ¶rse Stuttgart Digital Exchange, and now stablecoin plumbing at scale at MoonPay (after MoonPay acquired his company IRON).

Max explains what â€œrunning stablecoinsâ€ really means once you move beyond headlines: connecting on-chain money to the messy world of bank accounts, compliance, and regional payment rails. We dig into why UX still matters even in infrastructure, how developer experience becomes a moat, and why DeFi-native teams have an edgeâ€”because todayâ€™s rails were battle-tested in trading long before they became mainstream payments tech.

Youâ€™ll hear how IRON compresses what used to take months of integrations with multiple banks and PSPs into a single API: virtual IBANs/accounts that auto-convert fiat into stablecoins, plus global payouts into dozens of currencies. Max shares lessons from integrating into MoonPayâ€™s licensing stack (including MiCA) and why regulation is increasingly â€œtable stakesâ€ while operations and distribution decide winners. He also weighs in on Stripe/Tempo, why new â€œpayment chainsâ€ are mainly go-to-market plays, and whatâ€™s still unsettled around stablecoin yields and uneven enforcement across jurisdictions.

We debate incentives vs. liquidity, the rise of custom-issued stablecoins, and whether branded tokens will stick. Finally, Max looks ahead to a world where we stop saying â€œstablecoinsâ€ and simply call it moneyâ€”because the blockchain layer fades into the background.

Key topics: â€¢ Building stablecoin rails at scale â€¢ Virtual IBANs, on/off-ramps, global payouts â€¢ Adoption: wallets, fintechs, PSPs, and banks

item.title: Store of Bitcoin - Bitcoin as Store of Value â€“ Ep. 49 - Daniel Batten | A new different wave of Bitcoin Adopters.
item.description:
In this episode of Store of Bitcoin, host Alessandro Ottaviani welcomes Daniel Batten, a prominent Bitcoin analyst and investor, to discuss the evolving narrative surrounding Bitcoin, particularly in relation to energy consumption and environmental impact. Daniel shares insights on how the mainstream media's perception of Bitcoin has shifted from skepticism to a more favorable view, largely due to rigorous research and advocacy from the Bitcoin community. He emphasizes the importance of effectively communicating Bitcoin's benefits to various stakeholders, including policymakers and investors, to foster broader adoption.

The conversation delves into the challenges of reaching new adopters, particularly those who may not be motivated by the same values that initially attracted early Bitcoin enthusiasts. Daniel highlights the need for a more nuanced approach to education and outreach, focusing on the social and environmental benefits of Bitcoin. He also discusses the potential for Bitcoin to serve as a tool for financial inclusion in developing countries, where it can provide a safeguard against inflation and empower individuals in oppressive regimes. The episode concludes with a look at future trends in Bitcoin adoption and the importance of aligning messaging with the values of diverse audiences.

From the opening salvo, Gary drops bombs: "Bitcoin is the primary business without an HR department," freeing him from "dumb meetings about dumb subjects" to pursue art and self-discovery.

The crew dismantles fiat's "treadmill" (Larry: "The only thing more limited than Bitcoin is your timeâ€”and Bitcoin gives it back"), warns of ethical "prostitution" in corporate ladders, and reveals how creatives spot Bitcoin's magic first by thinking outside the box. Bob slams public miners' impending doom amid 2025's $8.6B M&A frenzy and harsh margins, while championing decentralized energy "sinkholes" for wasted power.

Larry's prescient "big print" prophecy hits home as the Fed ended QT in December 2025, restarting QE with $40B/month Treasury buys amid liquidity strainsâ€”fueling Bitcoin's hedge role despite its dip to ~$87K from $126K highs. They debate deflationary shocks from immigration policies, why success isn't chasing dollars (Gary: "Even billionaires don't get freedom"), and raw advice for young stackers: ditch consumerism, seek mentors, pay yourself first with 10% in BTC for compounding magic.This is the orange-pill blueprint for boomers and millennials alikeâ€”escape fiat's rat race before the next debasement wave.

item.title: Bitcoiners - Live From Bitcoin Beach â€“ How El Salvador Forced This Crypto Billionaire to Use Bitcoin (Proof The Circular Economy Works)
item.description:
Can a rural village in El Salvador actually replace the central bank?

Host Jethro Toro hangs out with Mike Peterson and the founders of Bitcoin Berlin, Evelyn Lemus and Gerardo Linares. They talk about a grassroots movement that is changing how people use money. We explore the true story of El Zonte, where a project focused on community development built a true circular economy. They used the Lightning Network to make fast digital payments just to survive the pandemic proving the experts wrong years before big banks caught on.

Evelyn and Gerardo explain exactly how they got a whole town excited about Bitcoin without asking the government for permission. We follow their journey from the coast to the mountains of Berlin. They are teaching high school students about decentralized finance so they can run their own independent systems instead of trusting apps to hold their money. They also highlight how El Salvador tourism is booming as Bitcoin fans visit to support local shop owners who are saving in Bitcoin.

We also look at how they are fighting back against expensive money transfer companies. You will learn how a new project in La Laguna uses a local hardware store to help families send money home without paying Western Union's high fees. The team explains why they stopped using the government's Chivo wallet to use better open tools. They even share a new guide for anyone who wants to start a Bitcoin community in their own neighborhood.

Subscribe to the channel to see the proof that this works, and leave a comment if you are ready to try a new way of using money.

item.title: Bitcoin Audible â€“ Read_929 - Bitcoin, Stoicism, and Our Relationship With Time
item.description:
"Imagine the Stanford marshmallow experiment in reverse. Instead of getting a second marshmallow for waiting, the children are told that every fifteen minutes they wait, the marshmallow in front of them will shrink one tiny bite at a time, until nothing remains. Naturally, they eat their marshmallow immediately, not out of impatience or hunger, but common sense. That's exactly how our money works today."

~Â Connor Dolan

What if the real cost of our broken money isn't just inflationÂ â€“ but the slow erosion of your ability to even imagine a future worth building toward?

This episode explores the surprising connection between Bitcoin, Stoicism, and the question we're all really asking: how should I be spending my time? From the marshmallow experiment in reverse to debt as invisible strings, we dig into why sound money might be the ultimate productivity hackÂ â€“ and why fiat is designed to keep you dependent, distracted, and disconnected from the life you actually want.

item.title: Thank God for Bitcoin â€“ Episode 74 The End of The Beginning of TGFB
item.description:
In this episode of the TGFB podcast, hosts Jordan Bush and Ahshuwah Hawthorne discuss the transition of TGFB to a nonprofit organization. They explore the challenges faced as a for-profit entity, the importance of serving the Christian Bitcoin community, and the collaboration with Brilliance Labs to enhance their mission. The conversation also covers the logistics of donations and the future vision for TGFB, emphasizing the need for community support and engagement.

You can read Jordan's summary here: https://economicsofglory.substack.com/p/a-new-era-for-thank-god-for-bitcoin?r=ep83x

And you can donate to support TGFB's work via Brilliance Labs here: http://brilliancelabs.org/tgfb

]]>

item.description:
In this episode of the Verified Podcast by Bitcoin Suisse, Dominic Weibel sits down with investment strategist DenisÂ Oevermann, crypto market analyst LucaÂ Gnos, and junior portfolio manager Mateo Sansonetti to dissect crypto's performance in 2025 and share their predictions for 2026.Â 
Â 
The discussion examines why 2025 was a year where crypto overdelivered on fundamentals but underdelivered on price. The panel explores new regulatory frameworks, the pro-crypto stance of the U.S. administration, and the disjointed performance between Bitcoin and altcoins. They analyze the explosive growth of options trading, the rise of prediction markets, and how macroeconomic factors and institutional flows will shape 2026.Â 
Â 
The conversation also tackles AI's market influence, the potential for Federal Reserve rate cuts, retail sentiment versus institutional positioning, and price predictions for Bitcoin and Ethereum heading into the new year.

item.title: Epicenter - Learn about Crypto, Blockchain, Ethereum, Bitcoin and Distributed Technologies â€“ How Will Stablecoins Replace Traditional Banking
item.description:
In this episode, we are joined by Zach Abrams, CEO of Bridge, to unpack the infrastructure behind the next generation of global payments. Zach discusses Bridgeâ€™s mission to move stablecoins beyond mere trading use cases and into core financial services, a vision that recently led to its landmark acquisition by Stripe . He explains how stablecoins function as an innovation at every layer of the money stack, enabling payments that are fundamentally faster and cheaper than legacy systems like ACH or SEPA.


They delve into the technical "puzzle pieces" of payments, from the inefficiencies of FBO bank accounts to the "cheat code" of compounding growth in the stablecoin sector. Zach introduces the concept of Stablecoin Orchestration and details why the current USDC/USDT duopoly is unaligned with high-velocity payments due to rent-seeking burn fees and AUM-focused models . Finally, the conversation explores the future of consumer finance, where non-custodial wallets act as bank replacements and a pluralistic ecosystem of local, company-issued stablecoins challenges the dominance of the US dollar


Topics


  • 00:00 Intro & Context
  • 04:15 Legacy Rails vs. Stablecoin Innovation
  • 09:30 The "Cash App" Hack & Payments Creativity
  • 15:00 Why Bridge Joined Stripe
  • 21:45 Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy of Startup Needs
  • 27:10 Stablecoin Orchestration & Issuance Explained
  • 35:20 The Duopoly Problem: Why USDC/USDT Isn't Enough
  • 42:15 Orthogonal Competition: The "Europe" of Stablecoins
  • 49:00 Wallets as the New Primary Bank Account
  • 55:30 Regrets of a "Child of the Depression" Founder
